newsitem.title: GERMANY: Bombing of Iraq "dangerous precedent" -- Primakov.
newsitem.headline: Bombing of Iraq "dangerous precedent" -- Primakov.

text.p: Russian Foreign Minister Yevgeny Primakov said on Wednesday the U.S. missile strikes on Iraq were setting a dangerous precedent.
"It's a very dangerous situation, a precedent for the future," he told a news conference after meeting his German counterpart Klaus Kinkel.

"If... we have a superpower, be it the United States, Europe or Russia, acting on its own initiative to use violence in a region without consulting an international organisation, in this case the U.N. Security Council, there will be conflict."
It was the third time in two days that Primakov had voiced strong public criticism of the U.S. action.
In Vaduz, Liechtenstein, earlier in the day he had sounded a warning that the strikes could unleash "catastrophic consequences" and "anarchy" on the world scene.

At the Bonn news conference, he said the U.S. action, intended to punish Baghdad for sending its forces to attack Kurds in a U.N.-implemented no-fly area in the north of the country, was not covered by any U.N. resolution.

"We need to keep to a system where force (against a sovereign country) is used only by the Security Council," Primakov said, citing examples such as Yugoslavia where joint international efforts had dealt with conflicts.
"There are plenty of other regions where we are working for stabilisation jointly," he said.
in Moscow, President Boris Yeltsin's chief-of-staff, Anatoly Chubais, said Yeltsin viewed the U.S. raids on Iraq as "very dangerous", and that further strikes would be "impermissible".
For years under the old Soviet system, Primakov was an academic specialist on the Middle East who frequently met Iraqi President Saddam Hussein.
Speaking in Berne on Tuesday, shortly after the first wave of U.S. missile strikes, he had suggested that they had been launched in part to help President Bill Clinton's re-election bid.
The attacks, he said, "cannot be supported by anyone at all, except those who put domestic politics, including pre-electoral questions, above all else."
